author: By     Jurica Dujmovic
title: Big Brother is watching you read this article
text:
As a designer and marketing professional, I spend a lot of time creating graphics for ads, as well as devising and running various online campaigns for my clients’ companies.
In those campaigns, we collect useful information about our users and visitors (in accordance with my clients’ privacy policies and with full consent of our customers and prospects), in order to serve them more appropriate content and a better service.
That is all part of the regular online marketing strategy that almost every modern company employs nowadays — it is the basis for understanding customers and growing one’s business.
www.mindofmareting.net However, there is a darker side to marketing. When companies want more of your info than you’re willing to provide, instead of risking expensive and potentially ineffective marketing campaigns, they hire people who know more about you than you think is possible. Those so-called data brokers are in business to collect and sell your private and personal data — typically without your consent. Information collected in this fashion is used for various purposes, ranging from simple identity verification to fraud detection, detailed “people search“ and for “optimizing” different marketing campaigns. Here are a few facts about data brokers you might not know:
Data brokers collect and store billions of data elements covering nearly every U.S. consumer. To collect and consolidate their efforts, they work together, with multiple layers of data brokers providing data to one another. Data brokers then combine and analyze the data to make inferences about consumers, some of which could potentially be sensitive. (i.e. those that primarily focus on ethnicity and income levels, such as “urban scramble” and “mobile mixers,” both of which include a high concentration of Latinos and African-Americans with low incomes). What do data brokers do with all that data? Here’s the paragraph from the Federal Trade Commission’s report on the issue, explaining the process:
Data brokers rely on websites with registration features and cookies to find consumers online and target Internet advertisements to them based on their offline activities. Once a data broker locates a consumer online and places a cookie on the consumer’s browser, the data broker’s client can advertise to that consumer across the Internet for as long as the cookie stays on the consumer’s browser. Consumers may not be aware that data brokers are providing companies with products to allow them to advertise to consumers online based on their offline activities. Some data brokers are using similar technology to serve targeted advertisements to consumers on mobile devices.
You might be wondering who these companies are. Here’s a short list:
Acxiom
Acxiom ACXM, -0.71% provides consumer data and analytics for marketing campaigns and fraud detection. Its databases contain information about 700 million consumers worldwide with over 3,000 data segments for nearly every U.S. consumer.
CoreLogic
CoreLogic CLGX, +1.11% provides data and analytic services to businesses and the government based primarily on property information, as well as consumer and financial data. Its databases include over 795 million historical property transactions, over 93 million mortgage applications, and property-specific data covering over 99% of U.S. residential properties, exceeding 147 million records.
Datalogix
Datalogix, owned by Oracle ORCL, +1.33% provides businesses with marketing data on almost every U.S. household and more than $1 trillion in consumer transactions. In September 2012, Facebook FB, +0.69% announced a partnership with Datalogix to measure how often Facebook’s 1 billion users see a product advertised on the social site and then complete the purchase in a brick-and-mortar retail store.
eBureau
eBureau provides predictive scoring and analytics services for marketers, financial-services companies, online retailers and others. It primarily offers products that predict whether someone is likely to become a profitable customer or whether a transaction is likely to conclude in fraud.
Intelius
The company provides businesses and consumers with background-check and public-record information. Its databases contain more than 20 billion records.
PeekYou
PeekYou has patented technology that analyzes content from over 60 social media sites, news sources, homepages and blog platforms to provide clients with detailed consumer profiles.
Rapleaf
Rapleaf is a data aggregator that has at least one data point associated with over 80% of all U.S. consumer email addresses. It supplements email lists with the email address owners’ age, gender, marital status and 30 other data points.
Recorded Future
Recorded Future captures historical data on consumers and companies across the Internet and uses that information to predict future behavior. As of May 2014, Recorded Future had access to information from over 500,000 open Internet sites.
